  • Fan: Noname but cool and it has a light :)

You can also notice I decorated the wall a little. Let’s talk about it: The right picture was drawn by my grandfather, who was an artist. The picture to the very left, I drew myself, as you might assume by the excellence of it. I got the picture of the Holy Family in Egypt from church. The silver cross was a gift from my cousin (also got it from church).

Also I have got the big Calendar from EVN, which I personally requested and was granted exclusive access on :D It’s really helpful as it grants me a perfect overview on all my exams.

As you might have recognized I got a little forearm training device which I use while coding or if I’m just bored… #neverStopTraining üí™

This is a blog project that reads Markdown files and converts them to HTML using Hugo üî•

Benefits

Hosting cost

Using this approach I am able to minimize hosting costs as far as possible, since only HTML files are served and I don’t require a database.

Theming

Hugo enables theming and many skilled designers have published their cool themes which can easily be imported and used. So, no more centering divs myself :)

Can I help?

Yes, you can. If you are familiar with Hugo and spot a flaw in my config files or just have a better approach, pls contact me via the contact section at my portfolio site eliaskelta.com!

item.title: The idea behind this
item.description: I always wanted to develop a post where I could write inspiring stuff about my life and programming carrier. But the problem always was, that hosting a big ass web app with a database and everything would result in high hosting cost. To avoid this, I came up with this solution: I write my posts in Markdown I translate the Markdown to HTML using Hugo I run a custom bash script to polish everything off I automatically publish the site to Vercel through a GitHub push
item.content:
I always wanted to develop a post where I could write inspiring stuff about my life and programming carrier. But the problem always was, that hosting a big ass web app with a database and everything would result in high hosting cost. To avoid this, I came up with this solution:

  • I write my posts in Markdown
  • I translate the Markdown to HTML using Hugo
  • I run a custom bash script to polish everything off
  • I automatically publish the site to Vercel through a GitHub push

item.content:
What is OpenRazer?

I recently acquired a new Razer mouse (Basilisk V3 X Hyperspeed) and wanted to modify it on Linux as well. That’s when I found OpenRazer. It is a community-led effort to support Razer peripherals on Linux. The driver supports hundreds of Razer devices, if not all of them.

How to use it

I really love the Linux community 4 things like this. The driver works like a charm. You can install many different programs that integrate with the OpenRazer driver. I personally use Polychromatic to control the DPI, RGB effects and basically every important setting I need.

SecureBoot

As for many 3rd party drivers on Linux, the drivers won’t be seen as safe by your systems BIOS per default. Luckily, OpenRazer have a tutorial regarding this here: https://github.com/openrazer/openrazer/wiki/Secure-Boot. Just follow the steps and it should work just fine:)
